title: How to Learn Common Phrases in Irish

steps.title: Dia Duit it literally means God be with you.
steps.content: Dia Duit it literally means God be with you. Whoever says Dia Duit first, the other person answers "Dia's Muire Duit" (dee-yass murra gwitch), which means God and Mary be with you, or 'Dia is Muire is Seosamh duit' (dee-ya iss murra is showsive gwitch) God, Mary and Joseph be with you. It's from a more religious time really

steps.title: Conas atá tú is pronounced Cunnis taw too.
steps.content: Conas atá tú is pronounced Cunnis taw too.

steps.title: You must reply "Tá mé..."
steps.content: You must reply "Tá mé..." When you get asked "Conas atá tú." Then there are different words you could put in after Tá mé: Go maith (good) (Gu ma) Go deas (great) (Gu dass) Go brón (sad) (Gu brone) Tá sceitimíní orm (excited) (Tah skettimeeni uram) "Tá mé go maith" (fine) (Tah may go mahth) "Tá mé beo ar éigean" (not so good) (Ta may be-or reagan)

steps.title: Say "go raibh maith agat" if someone hands you a gift.
steps.content: Say "go raibh maith agat" if someone hands you a gift. It means thank you and is pronounced gu-revv-ma-agut.

steps.title: Say "seo leat" when you hand somebody a gift.
steps.content: Say "seo leat" when you hand somebody a gift. It means: "here you go" and it is pronounced - shu latt.

steps.title: Say "tá fáilte romhat" if someone thanks you for something.
steps.content: Say "tá fáilte romhat" if someone thanks you for something. It's pronounced as "Taw fawlchta rowt" and means "you're welcome."

steps.title: Say "sián agat" when you're leaving.
steps.content: Say "sián agat" when you're leaving. The person remaining says, "Slán leat," which also means goodbye.

steps.title: Más é do thoil é
steps.content: Más é do thoil é is pronounced as "mawsh ay du hull ay."

steps.title: Gabh mo leithscéal is pronounced "Gohv moh lesh kale."
steps.content: Gabh mo leithscéal is pronounced "Gohv moh lesh kale." It means excuse me, or pardon.

steps.title: Say "Níl Gaeilge agam" (Kneel gwail ga ugum) if you don't know what someone's saying.
steps.content: Say "Níl Gaeilge agam" (Kneel gwail ga ugum) if you don't know what someone's saying. You can also say "Ní Thuigim" (Knee Higim), which means: "I don't understand."
